language.description:
Pronouns do not match sufficiently well for an immediate Trans New Guinea affiliation, and apart from this, there are only capricious lexical similarities to other families Voorhoeve 1975:396-398. Internally, Koneraw and Mombum (aka Komelom) can be seen to be related from the basic vocabulary correspondences in Geurtjens 1933.

language.description:
Laycock never presented real evidence for a Kwomtari-Baibai-Pyu family Laycock 1975. The membership is Kwomtari [kwo], Biaka/Nai [bio] and not Fas [fqs] as many sources have erroneously repeated. It is clear from the data collected so far Baron 1983 that Guriaso [grx] shares no more lexical cognates with Kwomtari and Biaka than expected at random, and thats not even when borrowing is discounted (Kwomtari neighbours Guriaso). Further correspondences presented are merely typological or random enough to make Japanese a Kwomtari language Baron 1983:29.

Baron, Wietze. (1983) Kwomtari Survey. Unpublished manuscript, SIL Survey office, Ukarumpa, now posted at link accessed 15 Dec 2008.  

Laycock, Donald C. (1975) Sko, Kwomtari and Left May (Arai) Phyla. In Stephen A. Wurm (ed.), New Guinea Area Languages and Language Study Vol 1: Papuan Languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene (Pacific Linguistics: Series C 38), 849-858. Canberra: Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, Australian National University.:Baron 1983

Baron, Wietze. (1983) Kwomtari Survey. Unpublished manuscript, SIL Survey office, Ukarumpa, now posted at link accessed 15 Dec 2008.

iso_retirement.comment:
The entry for Karen, Paku contained Mobwa as a dialect in the past. However, speakers of Mobwa report low inherent intelligibility with Paku. Based on low reported comprehension and separate identities, it seems that Mobwa should be considered a separate language from Paku. In addition, Mobwa is treated as a distinct variety from Paku in the linguistic literature.
Regarding Mobwa being different from Paku and from Sgaw, there is an article by Shintani (2001) in which he did lexicostatistical analysis of various Karen varieties, including Sgaw, Paku, and Mobwa. He found 79% similarity between Mobwa and Paku and put them in separate groupings. He found 74% similarity between Mobwa and Sgaw and put them in separate groupings.
The Mobwa live among the Bwe, but have to switch to Sgaw or Burmese to communicate with them. They do not have much contact with Paku people, have low understanding of Paku, and have a distinct identity from the Paku.
iso_retirement.name: Paku Karen
iso_retirement.remedy: Split into Paku Karen [jkp] and Mobwa Karen [jkm]

language.description:
Canonical source(s): Laycock and ZGraggen 1975, Conrad and Dye 1975, Conrad and Lewis 1988
Classification comment: Typological arguments are not sufficient to conclude a Leonard Schultze family with Walio Laycock and ZGraggen 1975. The lexical evidence does not show any conclusive genetic relationship either, be it inside or outside Leonard Schultze Conrad and Dye 1975, or with Duranmin Conrad and Lewis 1988 (a higher figure (29%) of Papi-Duranmin lexicostatistical relations quoted by Laycock earlier, is superseded by the later, below 10%, figures of Conrad and Lewis).


Conrad, Robert J. & T. Wayne Dye. (1975) Some language relationships in the Upper Sepik region of Papua New Guinea. In Papers in New Guinea Linguistics 18 (Pacific Linguistics: Series A 40), 1-35. Canberra: Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, Australian National University.

In Papers in New Guinea Linguistics 26 (Pacific Linguistics: Series A 76), 243-273. Canberra: Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, Australian National University.

Wurm (ed.), New Guinea Area Languages and Language Study Vol 1: Papuan Languages and the New Guinea linguistic scene (Pacific Linguistics: Series C 38), 731-764. language.description:
Canonical source(s): Trefry 1969
Classification comment: Despite vocabulary cognacy of 5% or so, Pawaia was included in Trans-New-Guinea because of pronoun resemblances to Kuman and on typological  similarities. The typological similarities involve function only Trefry 1969, and thus count for nothing. The pronoun resemblances do not generalize to the Chimbu family Foley 1986:69-71 and match only an emphn anyway, so they are better accounted for as accidental similarities than deep relationship.


Foley, William A. (1986) The Papuan languages of New Guinea (Cambridge language surveys). Cambridge University Press.  

Trefry, David. (1969) A Comparative Study of Kuman and Pawaian (Pacific Linguistics: Series B 13). Canberra: Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, Australian National University.
language.name: Pawaia

language.description:
Canonical source(s): Viegas Barros 2004
Classification comment: The best case for Payagua relatedness is with Guaycuru and/or Guachi Viegas Barros 2004 but the parallels are still insufficient.


Viegas Barros, Jose Pedro. (2004) Guaicuru no, macro-Guaicuru si: Una hipotesis sobre la clasificacion de la lengua Guachi (Mato Grosso do Sul, Brasil). Ms.
language.name: Payagua
